pullRequest.title: refactor(iot-dev): Use wait and notify to cut down on useless thread creation in transport layer
pullRequest.bodyText:
The current design of the device client library periodically spawns threads to handle sending and receiving messages as well as invoking callbacks. The device client will spawn these threads regardless of if any messages actually need to be sent/received, though.
With this change, the send/receive threads will instead wait until a message requires them to wake up. This will cut down on thread creation during less busy times without sacrificing performance during busy times
The second commit for this PR makes our DeviceIO layer more responsive to connection change events. Previously, if the transport layer went into reconnecting mode, the device IO layer would still spawn send/receive threads repeatedly even though they would be unable to send/receive anything since the transport isn't connected.

afterCommit.message:
fix(iot-dev): Fix issue where device client spawned send/receive threads even when transport is disconnected retrying

These threads cause the retry logic to hog a lot of resources and accomplished nothing since no messages can be sent/received when reconnecting

nodes.bodyText: Passing this in as a parameter so that the transpor layer can callback up to this layer when the connection status changes

This logic was moved to the connection status callback. That way, this method (which starts up the send/receive thread pool) gets called every time the client goes from DISCONNECTED or DISCONNECTED_RETRYING to CONNECTED. This allows the thread pool to not be active during DISCONNECTED_RETRYING

this method will be called back from the transport layer every time the state changes. This class should start/stop the send/receive thread pool and then update its own state to be consistent with the transport state

nodes.bodyText: See here for a more in-depth explanation on wait/notify, but the short of it is that this thread goes dormant until notified. When dormant, this thread has minimal performance impact on the machine running the SDK

commit.message:
refactor(iot-dev): Use wait and notify to cut down on useless thread creation in transport layer

The current design of the device client library periodically spawns threads to handle sending and receiving messages as well as invoking callbacks. The device client will spawn these threads regardless of if any messages actually need to be sent/received, though.

With this change, the send/receive threads will instead wait until a message requires them to wake up. This will cut down on thread creation during less busy times without sacrificing performance during busy times

fix(iot-dev): Fix issue where device client spawned send/receive threads even when transport is disconnected retrying

These threads cause the retry logic to hog a lot of resources and accomplished nothing since no messages can be sent/received when reconnecting

refactor(iot-dev): Separate task schedulers for send and receive tasks

Want to avoid a state where a unified task scheduler has 2 send tasks active at once, and neither have any work to do. This would block all receiving of messages. Better to just separate these schedulers into send and receive to avoid this

nodes.bodyText: Splitting this into two separate schedulers so that there is no chance of this thread pool of size 2 having two send tasks active at once, and both waiting for work to arrive. If that were to happen, then no receive threads will spawn, so any received messages will be stuck.
how are these managed when calls are made in parallel - i.e. I call open() over one thread, and then close() over another thread, at the same time.
shouldn't these status updates be made over a lock?

commit.message: refactor(iot-dev): Add state lock for synchronizing open/close at deviceIO level
